The '''Belyayev circle''' ({{lang-ru|'''Беляевский кружок'''}}) was a society of Russian musicians who met in [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]] between 1885 and 1908, and whose members included [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]], [[Alexander Glazunov]], [[Vladimir Stasov]], [[Anatoly Lyadov]], [[Alexander Ossovsky]], [[Witold Maliszewski]], [[Nikolai Tcherepnin]], [[Nikolay Sokolov (composer)|Nikolay Sokolov]], [[Alexander Winkler (composer)|Alexander Winkler]] among others. The circle was named after [[Mitrofan Belyayev]], a [[lumber|timber]] merchant and amateur musician who became a music philanthropist and publisher after hearing the music of the teenage Glazunov.
The Belyayev circle believed in a [[musical nationalism|national]] style of classical music, based on the achievements of the composer group [[The Five (composers)|The Five]] which preceded it. One important difference between composers in the Belyayev circle and their counterparts in the Five was an acceptance in the necessity of Western-styled academic training; this was an attitude passed down by Rimsky-Korsakov, who taught many of the composers in the circle at the [[Saint Petersburg Conservatory]]. While these composers were more open to Western compositional practices and influences, especially through the music of [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]], they closely followed many of the compositional practices of the Five to the point of mannerism, especially in their depiction of folkloric subject matter.
The Belyayev circle came to dominate musical life in St. Petersburg. Composers who desired patronage, publication or public performance of their works through Belyayev were compelled to write in a musical style accepted by Glazunov, Lyadov and Rimsky-Korsakov. There was also peer pressure to compose in this style, as well as a distrust of composers who did not do so. Several composers who believed in the philosophy of the Belyayev circle became professors and heads of music conservatories in Russia, which extended the influence of the group past the physical confines of St. Petersburg and timewise well into the 20th century.
==Belyayev== {{see also|Mitrofan Belyayev}} [[File:Belyayev by Repin.jpg|thumb|180px|right|alt=A middle-aged man with medium-length dark hair and a beard, wearing a dark suit, with one hand in his trouser pocket and the other hand on his chin|Portrait of [[Mitrofan Belyayev]] by [[Ilya Repin]]]]
Belyayev was one of a growing number of Russian nouveau-riche industrialists who became patrons of the arts in mid- to late-19th century Russia; their number included Nadezhda von Meck, railway magnate [[Savva Mamontov]] and textile manufacturer [[Pavel Tretyakov]].<ref>Figes, 195–197; Maes, 173–174, 196–197.</ref> While Nadezhda von Meck insisted on anonymity in her patronage in the tradition of ''[[noblesse oblige]]'', Belyayev, Mamontov and Tretyakov "wanted to contribute conspicuously to public life".<ref name="taruskin49">Taruskin, 49.</ref> Because of their cultural and political orientation, they were more likely than the aristocracy to support native talent, and were more inclined to support nationalist artists over cosmopolitan ones.<ref name="taruskin42"/> This was not due to any social or political agenda implicit in the art, but due to the Russianness of the art itself.<ref name="taruskin42">Taruskin, 42.</ref> This included the music of the composers Belyayev chose to support.<ref name="taruskin42"/>
An amateur [[viola]] player and [[chamber music]] enthusiast, Belyayev hosted "[[string quartet|quartet]] Fridays" at his home in St. Petersburg. A frequent visitor to these gatherings was Rimsky-Korsakov.<ref>Maes, 172–173.</ref> Belyayev became a music patron after he had heard the [[Symphony No. 1 (Glazunov)|First Symphony]] by the sixteen-year-old Glazunov, who had been discovered by Balakirev and tutored by Rimsky-Korsakov in musical composition, [[counterpoint]] and orchestration. Not only did Glazunov become a fixture of the "quartet Fridays", but Belyayev also published Glazunov's work and took him on a tour of Western Europe. This tour included a visit to [[Weimar]], [[Germany]] to present the young composer to famed Hungarian composer and pianist [[Franz Liszt]].<ref name="maes192">Maes, 192.</ref>
Soon Belyayev became interested in other Russian composers. In 1884 he set up an annual [[Glinka prize]], named after pioneer Russian composer [[Mikhail Glinka]] (1804–1857). In 1885 he founded his own music publishing firm, based in [[Leipzig]], Germany, through which he published works by Glazunov, Rimsky-Korsakov, Lyadov and Borodin at his own expense.<ref name="maes173"/> By publishing in Leipzig, Belyayev could offer the double benefit of higher quality music printing than was available in Russia at the time, plus the protection of international [[copyright]] which Russia did not offer.<ref name="taruskin49"/> At Rimsky-Korsakov's suggestion, Belyayev also founded his own concert series, the [[Russian Symphony Concerts]], open exclusively to Russian composers. Among the works written especially for this series were the three by Rimsky-Korsakov by which he is currently best known in the West—''[[Scheherazade]]'', the ''[[Russian Easter Festival Overture]]'' and ''[[Capriccio espagnol]]''. To select which composers to assist with money, publication or performances from the many who now appealed for help, Belyayev set up an advisory council made up of Glazunov, Lyadov and Rimsky-Korsakov. They would look through the compositions and appeals submitted and suggest which composers were deserving of patronage and public attention.<ref name="maes173">Maes, 173.</ref>
==Influence== The musical scene in St. Petersburg came to be dominated by the Belyayev circle since Rimsky-Korsakov had taught many of its members at the Conservatory there. Since Glazunov, Lyadov and Rimsky-Korsakov acted in an advisory capacity to the Belyayev enterprises, and thus became channels of Belyayev's largesse,<ref name="taruskin56"/> composers who wished to be part of this circle and who desired Belyayev's patronage had to write in a musical style approved by these three men.<ref name="maes173"/> Because of this stricture, Rimsky-Korsakov's style became the preferred academic style—one that young composers had to follow if they hoped to have any sort of career.<ref name="maes173">Maes, 173.</ref> In this sense, the Belyayev circle acted as a compositional [[guild]].<ref name="taruskin56"/> The better pupils from the St. Petersburg Conservatory received initiation by their invitation to the "quartet Fridays", and admission to the circle "guaranteed well remunerated publication by Edition Belieff, Leipzig, and performance in the Russian Symphony Concert programs".<ref name="taruskin56">Taruskin, 56.</ref> Thus, the Belyayev circle "set up an establishment that governed all aspects of musical creation, education and performance".<ref name="taruskin56"/>
==Philosophy== The Belyayev circle ran counter in its philosophy to the artistic movement and magazine ''[[Mir iskusstva]]'' ({{lang-ru|«Мир иску́сства»}}, ''World of Art''). ''Mir iskusstva'' "identified with the artistic values of the [Russian] aristocracy" in its cosmopolitanism and belief of a universal culture.<ref>Figes, 268–269.</ref> The composers of the Belyayev circle, like the Five before it, believed in a national, realist form of Russian classical music that should stand apart in its style and characteristics from Western European classical music. In this sense, the Belyayev composers shared similar goals with the [[Abramtsevo Colony]] and [[Russian Revival architecture|Russian Revival]] in the sphere of fine arts. Another way ''Mir iskusstva'' disagreed with the Belyayev circle was that they believed the composers under Belyayev were practicing art for art's sake, much like a social program. This practice ran counter to their belief in focusing on "art as the spiritual expression of the individual's creative genius", as they felt [[Alexander Pushkin]] had done in his poetry and Tchaikovsky in his music.<ref>Figes, 269.</ref> Alfred Nurok commented in an 1899 review in ''Mir iskusstva'':
{{quote|Mr. Belyayev's [[Gaius Maecenas|Maecenas]] activities bear a very special imprint. His undeniably lavish patronage of Russian music of the newest variety does not, unfortunately, so much facilitate the development of the talents of gifted but as yet unrecognized composers, as it encourages young people who have successfully completed their conservatory course to cultivate productivity come what may, touching little upon the question of their creative abilities. Mr. Belyayev encourages industry above all, and under his [[aegis]] musical composition has assumed the character of a workers' collective (''[[artel]]''), or even a crafts industry.|<ref>As cited in Maes, 173.</ref>}}
Musicologist [[Richard Taruskin]] writes, "Within the Belyayev circle a safe conformism became increasingly the rule".<ref name="taruskin57">Taruskin, 57.</ref> Concert programs needed to be filled with new Russian works, and new works had to be published to offer to the music public. It was therefore necessary "to dip rather deep into the pool of available Conservatory trained talent", and the circle became known for the number of less-than-first-rate talents harbored within it.<ref name="taruskin57"/> Critic and composer [[César Cui]], who had been part of the Five along with Rimsky-Korsakov, derisively called these younger composers "clones".<ref name="taruskin57"/> Though there was some snobbism involved in criticism of the Belyayev circle, there was also enough truth in the issue of conformism to cause the circle some embarrassment.<ref name="taruskin57"/> A contributing factor to this conformism was the gradual academization of composers in the nationalist circle, fueled by Rimsky-Korsakov's efforts in this regard with his students.<ref name="mfw21403">Frolova-Walker, ''New Grove (2001)'', 21:403.</ref> An increasing number of these students joined the Belyayev circle; the result was "the emergence of production-line 'Russian style' pieces, polished and correct, but lacking originality".<ref name="mfw21403"/>
==Comparison to the Five== [[File:Glazunov by Repin.jpg|thumb|alt=A young man with reddish hair wearing a dark suit|Portrait of [[Alexander Glazunov]] by [[Ilya Repin]], 1887]]
The composers who formed the Belyayev circle were nationalistic in their outlook, as were the Five before them. Like the Five, they believed in a uniquely Russian style of classical music that utilized folk music and exotic melodic, harmonic and rhythmic elements, as exemplified by the music of Balakirev, Borodin and Rimsky-Korsakov. Unlike the Five, these composers also believed in the necessity of an academic, Western-based background in composition. The necessity of Western compositional techniques was something that Rimsky-Korsakov had instilled in many of them in his years at the St. Petersburg Conservatory.<ref name="maes192"/> Compared to the "revolutionary" composers in Balakirev's circle, Rimsky-Korsakov found those in the Belyayev circle to be "progressive ... attaching as it did great importance to technical perfection, but ... also broke new paths, though more securely, even if less speedily...."<ref name="rk286">Rimsky-Korsakov, 286–287.</ref>
Glazunov's attitude toward outside influences was typical of the Belyayev circle. He studied Tchaikovsky's works and "found much that was new ... that was instructive for us as young musicians. It struck me that Tchaikovsky, who was above all a lyrical and melodic composer, had introduced operatic elements into his symphonies. I admired the thematic material of his works less than the inspired unfolding of his thoughts, his temperament and the constructural perfection."<ref>Quoted in Lobanova, 6.</ref> Rimsky-Korsakov noted "a tendency toward [[eclecticism]]" among the composers in the Belyayev circle, as well as a "predilection ... for Italian-French music of the time of wig and [[farthingale]] [that is, the eighteenth century], music introduced by Tchaikovsky in his ''[[The Queen of Spades (opera)|Queen of Spades]]'' and ''[[Iolanthe (Tchaikovsky)|Iolanthe]]''".<ref>Rimsky-Korsakov, 309.</ref>
Nevertheless, while the Belyayev circle was more tolerant of outside influence to a certain degree than their predecessors under Balakirev,<ref>Schwarz, ''New Grove (1980)'', 7:428.</ref> they still followed the compositional practices of the Five closely. Maes writes, "The harmonies of [[Modest Mussorgsky|Mussorgsky]]'s coronation scene in ''[[Boris Godunov (opera)|Boris]]'', the [[octatonic scale|octatonicism]] of ''[[Mlada (Rimsky-Korsakov)|Mlada]]'' and ''[[Sadko (opera)|Sadko]]'', Balakirev's folk-song stylizations, Rimsky-Korsakov's colorful [[harmony|harmonization]]—all these served as a store of recipes for writing Russian national music. In the portrayal of the national character ... these techniques prevailed over the subjects portrayed".<ref name="maes192"/>
==Folklorism, orientalism, "fantastic" style== Unlike their predecessors in the Five, composers in the Belyayev circle did not concern themselves greatly with [[fakelore|folklorism]]—the invention or adaptation of [[folklore]] to newly written stories or songs, or to folklore that is reworked and modified for modern tastes. They also did not travel to other parts of Russia to actively search for folk songs, as Balakirev had done. When the Belyayev composers produced folkloric works, "they simply imitated Balakirev's or Rimsky-Korsakov's styles".<ref>Maes, 192–193.</ref>
One of the Belyayev composers, [[Mikhail Ippolitov-Ivanov]], continued the Five's work in musical [[orientalism]]—the use of exotic melodic, harmonic and rhythmic elements to depict the middle- and far-eastern parts of the [[Russian Empire]].<ref>Figes, 390–391; Maes, 80–83.</ref> He wrote three operas set in an oriental background and composed in Balakirev's style—''Ruth'', ''Azra'' and ''Izmena''. The story for the last of these operas "deals with the struggle between Christians and Muslims during the sixteenth-century occupation of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] by the Persians".<ref name="maes193">Maes, 193.</ref> Ippolotov-Ivanov is best known in the West for his two sets of ''[[Caucasian Sketches]]'' "an orientalist orchestral work modeled on Balakirev and Borodin".<ref name="maes193"/>
Lyadov wrote in a "fantastic" vein akin to Rimsky-Korsakov's, especially in his tone poems based on Russian fairy tales, ''Baba Yaga'', ''Kikimora'' and ''The Enchanted Lake''.<ref name="maes192">Maes, 192.</ref> This style of musical writing was based on extensive use of the [[whole tone scale]] and the [[octatonic scale]] to depict supernatural or magical characters and events, hence the term "fantastic".<ref>Maes, 83–84.</ref> Though he would break from the Belyayev aesthetic in subsequent works, [[Igor Stravinsky]] wrote his [[Ballet (music)|ballet]] ''[[The Firebird]]'' in a similar musical style.<ref>Maes, 219.</ref>
==Intolerance of non-compliant composers== [[File:Young Rachmaninoff 2.jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A clean-shaven young man with close-cropped hair, wearing a dark jacket, dress shirt with a high stiff collar and tie, looking toward the viewer with one hand on the side of his head|Sergei Rachmaninoff]]
Despite Rimsky-Korsakov's denial of bias among composers of the Belyayev circle,<ref name="rk286"/> musicologist [[Solomon Volkov]] mentions that they and the Five shared a mutual suspicion of compositions that did not follow its canon.<ref name="volkov350">Volkov, ''St. Petersburg'', 350.</ref> This proved especially true of the [[Symphony No. 1 (Rachmaninoff)|First Symphony]] of [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]], a Moscow composer and protege of Tchaikovsky. Rimsky-Korsakov, whose own musical preferences in his later years were not overly progressive,<ref>Maes, 180—181.</ref> may have sounded an advance warning on hearing the symphony in rehearsal when he told Rachmaninoff, "Forgive me, but I do not find this music at all agreeable".<ref>Bertenssohn and Leyva, 71.</ref> By the reports of many present, the rehearsal that Rimsky-Korsakov had heard, conducted by Glazunov, was both a disaster as a performance and a horrific travesty of the score.<ref name="har76">Harrison, 76.</ref> The premiere, held in St. Petersburg on March 28, 1897, went no better. Cui wrote in his review of the work, among other things, "If there were a [[College or university school of music|conservatory]] in [[Hell]], and if one of its talented students were to compose a programme symphony based on the story of the [[Plagues of Egypt|Ten Plagues of Egypt]], and if he were to compose a symphony like Mr. Rachmaninoff's, then he would have fulfilled his task brilliantly and would delight the inhabitants of Hell".<ref>Cui, Ts., "Tretiy russkiy simfonicheskiy kontsert," ''Novosti i birzhevaya gazeta'' (17 March 1897(o.s.), 3.</ref> The symphony was not performed again in Rachmaninoff's lifetime,<ref>Bertenssohn and Leyva, 74.</ref> and while Rachmaninoff did not destroy or disavow the score, he suffered a psychological collapse that led to a three-year creative hiatus.<ref>Bertenssohn and Leyva, 144–145; Norris, ''Rachmaninoff'', 97.</ref>
==Modernism== Maes writes that the composers who formed the Belyayev circle have often been described as "important links to, and pathbreakers for" modernist Russian composers such as Stravinsky and [[Sergei Prokofiev]]. This, he asserts, is actually a false assumption which suggests that modernism was the result of a gradual process.<ref name="maes195">Maes, 195.</ref> The truth, Maes suggests, was that modernist music in Russia was a much more radical break from the Belyayev circle than many have claimed.<ref name="maes195"/> Rimsky-Korsakov's extensive use of the [[octatonic scale]] and other harmonic experiments "was a gold mine for those bent on a modernist revolution," Maes writes. "However, the renewing force had still to be liberated from the cliches and routines into which the Belyayev aesthetic had been pressed".<ref name="maes195"/>
==Legacy== [[File:Dmitrij Dmitrijevič Šostakovič (Дми́трий Дми́триевич Шостако́вич).jpg|thumb|upright|alt=A young man wearing round-framed glasses, a dark jacket, tie and dress shirt|Dmitri Shostakovich, 1925]]
Bias toward the musical aesthetics practiced by the Belyayev circle would continue at the St. Petersburg Conservatory after Rimsky-Korsakov's retirement in 1906,<ref>Taruskin, 73.</ref> with his son-in-law [[Maximilian Steinberg]] in charge of composition classes at the Conservatory through the 1920s.<ref>Wilson, 37.</ref> [[Dmitri Shostakovich]] would complain about Steinberg's musical conservatism, typified by such phrases as "the inviolable foundations of the ''kuchka''" and the "sacred traditions of Nikolai Andreyevich [Rimsky-Korsakov]".<ref>Letter from Shostakovich to Tatyana Glivenko dated February 26, 1924. As quoted in Fay, 24.</ref> Nor was this traditionalism limited to St. Petersburg. Well into the Soviet era, many other music conservatories remained run by traditionalists such as Ippolitov-Ivanov in Moscow and [[Reinhold Glière]] in [[Petro Tchaikovsky National Music Academy of Ukraine|Kiev]]. Because of these individuals, Maes writes, "the conservatories retained a direct link with the Belyayev aesthetic".<ref>Maes, 244.</ref>

ISBN n/a. * Fay, Laurel, ''Shostakovich: A Life'' (Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 2000). {{ISBN|0-19-518251-0}}. * Figes, Orlando, ''Natasha's Dance: A Cultural History of Russia'' (New York: Metropolitan Books, 2002). {{ISBN|0-8050-5783-8}} (hc.). * Frolova-Walker, Marina, "Rimsky-Korsakov. {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} The '''Brat Pack''' is a nickname given to a group of young actors who frequently appeared together in teen-oriented [[:Category:Coming-of-age films|coming-of-age films]] in the 1980s. First mentioned in a 1985 [[New York (magazine)|''New York'']] magazine article, it is now usually defined as the cast members of two specific films released in 1985—''[[The Breakfast Club]]'' and ''[[St. Elmo's Fire (film)|St. Elmo's Fire]]''—although other actors are sometimes included. The "core" members are considered to be [[Emilio Estevez]], [[Anthony Michael Hall]], [[Rob Lowe]], [[Andrew McCarthy]], [[Demi Moore]], [[Judd Nelson]], [[Molly Ringwald]], and [[Ally Sheedy]]. ==Membership== The term "Brat Pack", a play on the [[Rat Pack]] from the 1950s and 1960s, was first popularized in a 1985 ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine cover story, which described a group of highly successful film stars in their early twenties.{{cite journal |url=http://nymag.com/movies/features/49902/ | last=Blum |first=David |authorlink=David Blum |date=June 10, 1985|title=Hollywood's Brat Pack |journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |volume= |issue= |pages=40–47}} [[David Blum]] wrote the article after witnessing several young actors (Emilio Estevez, Rob Lowe, and Judd Nelson) being mobbed by groupies at Los Angeles' [[Hard Rock Cafe]].Mansour, David. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=hK0rPUF85loC&printsec=frontcover From Abba to Zoom: A Pop Culture Encyclopedia of the Late 20th Century]'' (Andrews McMeel Publishing, 2005), p. 56. The group has been characterized by the partying of members such as [[Robert Downey Jr.]], Estevez, Lowe, and Nelson.{{cite news |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |author2=Steven Paul Davies |date=December 15, 2000 |title=The year of the brat |journal=[[The Guardian]]|url=http://film.guardian.co.uk/features/featurepages/0,,411528,00.html |accessdate= 2008-03-19}} However, an appearance in one or both of the ensemble casts of [[John Hughes (filmmaker)|John Hughes]]' ''The Breakfast Club'' and [[Joel Schumacher]]'s ''St. Elmo's Fire'' is often considered the prerequisite for being a core Brat Pack member.{{cite news |last=Fine |first=Marshall |title=Remember the Brat Pack? Well, Now That They're Grown Up... |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 24, 1993 |page=20 }}{{cite book|title=Brat Pack: Confidential |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |author2=Steven Paul Davies |year=2000 |publisher=B T Batsford |url=http://www.bratpackconfidential.com |isbn=978-0-7134-8685-8 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080219235500/http://www.bratpackconfidential.com/ |archivedate=February 19, 2008 }}{{cite news |last=Eaton |first=Andrew |title=For a short time they were on fire, then they vanished into obscurity. Whatever happened to the Brat Pack of the 1980s? |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-13099506.html |publisher=''[[The Scotsman]]'' |date=January 20, 2007 |accessdate=2008-03-28 |newspaper=The Scotsman }} With this criterion, the most commonly cited members include:{{cite web |url=http://www.thebratpacksite.com |title=The Brat Pack Site|publisher=The Brat Pack Site|accessdate=2008-03-18 |last=Currie |first=Jamie |year=2003 }}{{cite episode|series=The E! True Hollywood Story|serieslink=The E! True Hollywood Story|title=The Brat Pack |accessdate=2008-03-18}}{{cite web |url=http://www.teenfi.com/movies/bratpack-5780.html |title=What Happened to the Brat Pack? |author=Earnshaw, Helen |publisher=''Teen First'' |date=July 18, 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-15}} * [[Emilio Estevez]] * [[Anthony Michael Hall]] * [[Rob Lowe]] * [[Andrew McCarthy]] * [[Demi Moore]] * [[Judd Nelson]] * [[Molly Ringwald]] * [[Ally Sheedy]] Absent from most lists is [[Mare Winningham]], the only principal member of either cast who never starred in any other films with any other cast members.{{cite web|url=http://www.bratpackconfidential.com/brat-pack.html |title=Brat Pack Confidential: The Players |publisher=Brat Pack Confidential|accessdate=2008-03-19 |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |author2=Davies, Steven Paul|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409133511/http://www.bratpackconfidential.com/brat-pack.html|archivedate=April 9, 2008}} Estevez was cited as the "unofficial president" of the Brat Pack. He and Demi Moore were once engaged. In 1999, McCarthy said he was never a member of the group: "The media made up this sort of tribe. I don't think I've seen any of these people since we finished ''St. Elmo's Fire''."Miller, Samantha and Jewel, Dan. [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20127981,00.html "Brat Race"]. ''People''. April 19, 1999. The initial ''New York'' article covered a group of actors larger, or more inclusive, than the currently understood meaning of the term "Brat Pack". For example, most of the cast members of ''[[The Outsiders (film)|The Outsiders]]'' were mentioned, including [[Tom Cruise]], [[C. Thomas Howell]], [[Matt Dillon]], [[Patrick Swayze]], and [[Ralph Macchio]], none of whom starred in any other 1980s movies with any "core" Brat Packers, besides [[Patrick Swayze]]. [[Charlie Sheen]] appears in several lists – more for his family relationship to Brat Pack leader Emilio Estevez and his partying than for his collaborative film work with other members. [[James Spader]] and [[Robert Downey, Jr.]] have also been considered members, and performed alongside other Brat Packers: both of them with Andrew McCarthy in ''[[Less Than Zero (film)|Less Than Zero]]''; Spader with McCarthy in ''[[Mannequin (1987 film)|Mannequin]]'' and with McCarthy and Molly Ringwald in ''[[Pretty in Pink]]''; and Downey with Anthony Michael Hall (''[[Weird Science (film)|Weird Science]]'' and ''[[Johnny Be Good]]''; and the cast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'') and with Molly Ringwald (''[[The Pick-up Artist (film)|The Pick-up Artist]]''). Other actors who have been linked with the group include [[Kevin Bacon]], [[Matthew Broderick]], [[Jon Cryer]], [[John Cusack]], [[Jami Gertz]], [[Mary Stuart Masterson]], [[Sean Penn]], [[Kiefer Sutherland]], and [[Lea Thompson]]. In her autobiography, [[Melissa Gilbert]] connects herself with the Brat Pack, as her social life centered on Estevez and Lowe (both of whom she was engaged to). Through frequent collaborative work, the actor [[Harry Dean Stanton]], then in his late 50s, became a mentor for the group of young actors. ==Article== David Blum's ''New York'' story, titled "Hollywood's Brat Pack", ran on June 10, 1985. It was originally supposed to be just about Emilio Estevez, but one night, Estevez invited Blum to hang out with him, Rob Lowe, Judd Nelson, and others at the Hard Rock Cafe. It was a typical night out for the group, who had gotten close while filming ''St. Elmo's Fire''. That night, Blum decided to change the article's focus to an entire group of young actors at the time. The ''St. Elmo's Fire'' crew members did not like Blum and sensed that he was jealous of the actors' success.Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried: The Brat Pack, John Hughes, And Their Impact on a Generation''. Three Rivers Press. pp. 106–119. When the piece ran, the actors all felt betrayed, especially Estevez. The article mentioned people in several films but focused on Estevez, Lowe, and Nelson, and portrayed those three negatively. The "Brat Pack" label, which the actors disliked, stuck for years afterward.{{Cite web|url=http://observer.com/1999/08/actor-andrew-mccarthy-is-bitter-about-brat-pack-past/|title=Actor Andrew McCarthy Is Bitter About Brat Pack Past|date=August 30, 1999|website=Observer|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-23}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Reason-Judd-Nelson-Hated-Brat-Pack-Label-86667.html|title=The Reason Judd Nelson Hated The Brat Pack Label|date=October 6, 2015|website=Cinemablend.com|access-date=2016-05-23}} Before the article ran, they had been regarded as talented individuals; after the article, all of them were grouped together and regarded as unprofessional. Interviewed for Susannah Gora's 2010 book ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried: The Brat Pack, John Hughes, And Their Impact on a Generation'', Blum admitted that he should not have written the article.Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried''. Three Rivers Press. pp. 117–128, 289–291, 336. With the increased negative attention to them, the actors soon stopped socializing with one another. On the group's camaraderie, Ally Sheedy later said, "[The article] just destroyed it. I had felt truly a part of something, and that guy just blew it to pieces."Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried''. Three Rivers Press. p. 128. ==Legacy== During the late 1980s, several of the Brat Pack actors had their careers mildly derailed by problems relating to drugs, alcohol, and in Lowe's case, a sex tape. According to Gora, "Many believe they could have gone on to more serious roles if not for that article. They were talented. But they had professional difficulties, personal difficulties after that."Wilson, Craig. [https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/news/2010-02-08-bratpack08_ST_N.htm "John Hughes and the Brat Pack, revisited"]. ''usatoday.com''. February 16, 2010. Retrieved 2011-01-24. By the 21st century, the term "Brat Pack" had lost its negative connotation.Gora, Susannah (2010). ''You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried''. Three Rivers Press. p. 332. The films themselves have been described as representative of "the socially apathetic, cynical, money-possessed and ideologically barren eighties generation."{{cite web |url=http://eightiesclub.tripod.com/id299.htm |title=13. The Brat Pack |accessdate=2008-03-18 |last=Manning |first=Jason |year=2000 |work=Material Things |publisher=The Eighties Club}}{{cite web|url=http://www.saxonbullock.com/don't%20you%20forget%20about%20me.htm |title=Don't You Forget About Me |author=Bullock, Saxon |publisher=Originally published in DVD Review |date=September 2004 |accessdate=2008-08-15 |quote=...ended up representing both the best and worst of the ambitious, materialistic 'Me' generation. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905165501/http://www.saxonbullock.com/don%27t%20you%20forget%20about%20me.htm |archivedate=September 5, 2008 }} They made frequent use of adolescent [[archetype]]s, were often set in the suburbs surrounding Chicago, and focused on white, middle-class teenage angst.{{cite journal |last=Lurie |first=Karen |title= Brat Pack |journal=St. James Encyclopedia of Popular Culture |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_g1epc/is_bio/ai_2419200128 |year=2002 }}{{cite web|last=Horwitz |first=Laura |title=The Brat Pack: 80's Icons |url=http://www.6degreesfilm.com/features.php?id=79 |accessdate=2008-03-28 |publisher=6 Degrees Film |year=2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081208073706/http://www.6degreesfilm.com/features.php?id=79 |archivedate=December 8, 2008 }} According to author Susannah Gora, these films "changed the way many young people looked at everything from class distinction to friendship, from love to sex and fashion to music." They are considered "among the most influential pop cultural contributions of their time."Gora, Susannah. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=XawD2yexM_kC&printsec=frontcover You Couldn't Ignore Me If You Tried: The Brat Pack, John Hughes, and Their Impact on a Generation]'' (Random House, Inc., 2010), p. 3. In 2012, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' listed ''The Breakfast Club'' as the best high school movie ever made.[http://www.ew.com/ew/gallery/0,,20483133_20632183_21215570,00.html "50 Best High School Movies"]. ew.com. September 22, 2012. Retrieved March 2, 2013. On [[VH1]]'s list of the 100 greatest teen stars, Molly Ringwald was ranked #1, Rob Lowe was ranked #2, Anthony Michael Hall was ranked #4, Ally Sheedy was ranked #34, and Andrew McCarthy was ranked #40.[https://web.archive.org/web/20060909103649/http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/the_greatest/97838/episode_featured_copy.jhtml "100 Greatest Teen Stars #'s 20-1"]. vh1.com. Retrieved March 2, 2013.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070103155515/http://www.vh1.com/shows/dyn/the_greatest/97837/episode_featured_copy.jhtml "100 Greatest Teen Stars #'s 40-21"]. vh1.com. Retrieved March 2, 2013. ==Filmography== Beyond the two primary films, there is no generally accepted list of "Brat Pack" movies. Molly Ringwald continued acting in films throughout the 1990s and in 2001, began performing as [[Sally Bowles]] in the Broadway revival of ''[[Cabaret (musical)|Cabaret]].'' In 2013, she released a jazz record called ''Except Sometimes"''.{{Cite news|url=http://gazettereview.com/2017/01/happened-molly-ringwald-news-updates/|title=What Happened to Molly Ringwald – News & Updates – The Gazette Review|last=Briscoe|first=Jake|date=January 11, 2017|work=The Gazette Review|access-date=2017-05-04|language=en-US}} She also began starring in television shows such as [[The Secret Life of the American Teenager|''The Secret Life of the American Teenage''r]] and [[Riverdale (2017 TV series)|''Riverdale'']]. [[Emilio Estevez]] and [[Judd Nelson]] also continued to act. Nelson has performed on three seasons on the show "[[Suddenly Susan]]" and "[[Bad Kids Go to Hell]]".{{Cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/movies/whatever-happened-to-emilio-estevez-ally-sheedy-molly-ringwald-judd-nelson-and-anthony-michael-hall-from-the-breakfast-club/news-story/30718ac13a55b4a0251579ee4efdc0be|title=Whatever happened to the Breakfast Club?|work=NewsComAu|access-date=2017-05-04|language=en}} [[Ally Sheedy]] has acted in more independent works and shows like [[Kyle XY]] and also she teaches at [[LaGuardia High School of Performing Arts|La Guardia High school of Performing Arts]]. Close contributor [[Robert Downey Jr.]] became one of the most successful actors since then. His most acclaimed character is [[Iron Man|Tony Stark / Iron Man]] in the 2008 [[Marvel Studios]] film ''[[Iron Man (2008 film)|Iron Man]]'', a role he later reprised in multiple sequels, several revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox coat of arms | image = Coat of Arms of Spanish Monarch.svg | image_width = 180 | armiger = [[Felipe VI of Spain|Felipe VI]] | year_adopted = 19 June 2014 | crest = [[Spanish Royal Crown]] | shield = [[Quartering (heraldry)|Quarterly]]: [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|Castile]], [[Coat of arms of Castile and León|León]], [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]], and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; enté en point: [[Granada]]; inescutcheon [[National Emblem of France|Bourbon (Anjou Branch)]] | supporters = | orders = [[Order of the Golden Fleece]] | other_elements = | earlier_versions = ''[[Coat of arms of the King of Spain#Ornamented versions of the historical royal coats of arms|See below]]'' }} The '''coat of arms of the King of Spain''' is the [[heraldic symbol]] representing the monarch of Spain. The current version of the monarch's coat of arms was adopted in 2014 but is of much older origin. The arms marshal the arms of the former monarchs of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castille]], [[Kingdom of León|León]], [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]], and [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]. Traditionally, coats of arms did not belong to a nation but to the monarch who would quarter his shield with territorial claims of his dynasty. Formerly, the Spanish monarch's arms were much more complex than they are today. It would feature the arms of the various territories of this dynasty. A simpler version of these arms, known as the ''lesser arms'', would also be used; This lesser arms were another set of arms within the centre of the full arms. During the later part of the Bourbon dynasty this would be quarterly Castille and Leon. In 1868, during the [[Provisional Government (1868-1871)|provisional government]] that followed the overthrow of Queen [[Isabella II]], an arms of ''national character'' was adopted; This 1868 arms created the present-day arrangement of elements in the shield. The "national arms" and "royal arms" would coexist after the restoration of the monarchy. In 1931, the royal arms was revised to incorporate what had been hitherto the "national arms" into the royal arms and to replace the former lesser arms of the King (i.e. quarterly Castille and Leon). The monarchy would later be abolished later that year. When don Juan Carlos, grandson of Alfonso XIII (the last king of Spain), was chosen to be the successor of General [[Francisco Franco]], the arms adopted for his use in 1971 as Prince of Spain was quarterly Castille, Leon, Aragon, and Navarre. The heraldic achievement also included the collar of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece]], the Cross of Burgundy and the yoke and bundle of arrows formerly used by the [[Catholic Monarchs]]; This would be the same arms he would use as King. Upon Felipe VI's ascension to the throne in 2014, the cross, yoke, and arrows would not be retained in the royal arms. ==Blazon== The [[blazon]]ing of the coat of arms of the King of Spain is set out in Royal Decree 527/2014, 20 June, an amendment to Title II of Spanish Royal Decree 1511/1977 adopting Flags, Standards, Guidons, Insignia and Emblems Regulation.{{cite web |url=http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2014/06/21/pdfs/BOE-A-2014-6525.pdf |title=Real Decreto 527/2014, de 20 de junio, por el que se crea el Guión y el Estandarte de Su Majestad el Rey Felipe VI y se modifica el Reglamento de Banderas y Estandartes, Guiones, Insignias y Distintivos, aprobado por Real Decreto 1511/1977, de 21 de enero. |date=20 June 2014 |website= BOE Spanish Official Journal|series= |publisher= |location= |page= |pages= |at= |language= Spanish|trans-title=Royal Decree 527/2014 setting up the Guidon and Standard of HM King Felipe VI and amends Standards, Guidons, Insignia and Emblems Regulation, adopted on Royal Decree 1511/1977|accessdate=2014-06-21}} The coat of arms was adopted when King [[Felipe VI of Spain|Felipe VI]] was enthroned as King of Spain.{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldo.es/noticias/nacional/2014/06/19/felipe_cuenta_con_escudo_guion_propios_294797_305.html |title=Felipe VI ya cuenta con escudo y guión propios |language=Spanish |trans-title=Felipe VI has his own coat of arms and guidon |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 2014-06-19|website=www.heraldo.es |publisher= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} The shield is divided into four quarters, blazoned as follows: *1st, [[gules]] a castle [[Or (heraldry)|or]], triple-embattled and voided gate and windows, with three towers each triple-turreted, of the field, masoned [[sable]] and ajoure [[azure (heraldry)|azure]], which is for [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]]; *2nd, [[argent]] a lion [[rampant]] purpure crowned or, langued and armed, of the second, which is for [[Kingdom of León|León]]; *3rd, or, four pallets gules, which is for [[Crown of Aragon|Aragon]]; *4th, gules a cross, saltire and orle of chains linked together or, a centre point vert, which is for [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]]; Argent enté en point, with a pomegranate proper seeded gules, supported, sculpted and leafed in two leaves vert, which is for [[Granada]]. Inescutcheon [[azure (heraldry)|azure]] [[bordure]] gules, three [[fleurs-de-lys]] or, which is for [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon-Anjou]]. All surrounded by the collar of the [[Order of the Golden Fleece|Golden Fleece]] and crowned with a crown of the same metal and precious stones, with eight rosettes, five visible, and eight pearls interspersed, closed at the top by eight diadems also adorned with pearls and surmounted by a cross on a globe, which is the royal crown of Spain.[http://www.casareal.es/sm_rey/armas-iden-idweb.html Coat of arms of His Majesty the King of Spain]. The Royal Household of the King of Spain. Retrieved 19 October 2011. In 1969, General [[Francisco Franco]] appointed [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|Juan Carlos I]] as his "successor to the Headship of the Spanish state with the title of King" but gave him the new title of [[Prince of Spain]] instead of the traditional title of [[Prince of Asturias]]. From 1971 to 1975, Juan Carlos as Prince of Spain used a coat of arms which was virtually identical to the one later adopted when he became King in 1975. Earlier coat of arms differed only that it featured the royal crown of a Crown Prince of Spain, the King's royal crown has eight half-arches of which five are visible, while the Prince's one has only four half-arches of which three are visible.{{es icon}} [http://www.armada.mde.es/ArmadaPortal/page/Portal/ArmadaEspannola/conocenos_historia/03_bandera_armada--14_miscelania--02_insignias_jefes_estado--05_juan_carlos_i_es ''Spanish Decree 814 of 22nd April 1971'']. Boletín Oficial del Estado, Official Gazette of the Spanish Government, no. 99. Retrieved 19 October 2011. Joined to the shield was the red saltire of [[Cross of Burgundy Flag|Burgundy]] and, to the dexter and sinister of the base point, the yoke gules in its natural position with ribbons, of the field, and the sheaf of five arrows gules with the arrowheads inverted and ribbons, of the field, which used to be the symbol of the [[Catholic Monarchs]] of Spain. Since June 2014, Juan Carlos's son, Felipe VI, has been using the same arms but without the cross of Burgundy, yoke and arrows.{{cite web |url=http://www.casareal.es/EN/FamiliaReal/rey/Paginas/rey_armas.aspx |title=Coat of arms of His Majesty King Juan Carlos |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 2014-06-19|website=Spanish Royal Household Website |publisher= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} King Juan Carlos's arms include a red lion instead of the purple one displayed on the current version{{cite web |url=http://www.casareal.es/EN/FamiliaReal/ReyFelipe/Paginas/principe_armas.aspx |language= |title= Coat of arms of His Majesty the King|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= 2014-06-19|website=Spanish Royal Household Website |publisher= |accessdate=2014-06-20}} == Variants ==

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{refimprove|date=July 2011}} {{Expert-subject|law|date=February 2012}} A '''deed of change of name''' is a legal document—used in the United Kingdom, Ireland and some other countries with [[legal system]]s based on English [[common law]]—for an official [[name change]] by a person or family. It is one use of a [[deed poll]].
Some organisations, such as government departments issuing passports and driving licences, may not recognise a name change without documentation, such as a deed or [[statutory declaration]]. However, an official document is not a legal requirement for a valid name change<ref>https://www.gov.uk/change-name-deed-poll/overview</ref> according to common law.<ref>http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1994/604/note/made</ref>
==Legal procedure== ===United Kingdom=== In [[England and Wales]], such a deed may be registered in the Central Office of the [[High Court of Justice of England and Wales|High Court]]. Deeds so registered are advertised in the ''[[London Gazette]]''. A deed of name change on behalf of a minor must be approved by the [[Judiciary of England and Wales|Senior Master]] on behalf of the [[Master of the Rolls]] who will take into account the child's [[best interests]]. A deed poll can also be used to change a child's name, as long as everyone with parental responsibility for the child consents to it<ref>{{cite web|title=Change a child’s name|url=https://www.gov.uk/change-name-deed-poll/change-a-childs-name|website=GOV.UK|accessdate=31 January 2015|quote=To change the name of a child aged under 16 (sometimes called a ‘minor’) you’ll need either: the agreement of everyone with parental responsibility [or] a court order}}</ref> and the child does not object to it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Changing your name|url=http://www.adviceguide.org.uk/england/relationships_e/relationships_birth_certificates_and_changing_your_name_e/changing_your_name.htm|website=AdviceGuide UK|accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref>
Registration of deeds is regulated by the ''Enrolment of Deeds (Change of Name) Regulations 1994'', [[Statutory Instrument|SI]] 1994/604<ref>{{cite web|url=http://legislation.data.gov.uk/cy/uksi/1994/604/made/data.htm?wrap=true |title=Enrolment of Deeds (Change of Name) Regulations 1994 |publisher=HM Government|website=legislation.data.gov.uk |date=4 July 2011 |accessdate=10 December 2016 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> (as amended<ref>[https://deedpolloffice.com/change-name/enrolling/enrolment-regulations/1994 Enrolment of Deeds (Change of Name) Regulations 1994 SI 1994/604 (as amended)]</ref>) . Compared to some other European countries, for example Germany, a name change in the UK is easy and virtually unrestricted regarding choice.
Registration of a deed of change of name is not a legal requirement in the United Kingdom. A standard legal document, with stock wording, filled in by the person making the deed poll, and signed in presence of a [[witness]], carries sufficient legal [[authority]] to be recognised. The witness need not be a solicitor but can be anyone over the age of 18 independent of the person changing their name.
The procedure, requirements and law surrounding the issue in [[Northern Ireland]] are similar to those in England and Wales. In England, Northern Ireland and Wales, a deed of change of name will not change the name on a birth certificate. For instance, when applying for a passport, both the certificate and the deed would need to be presented as documents of identity.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/614120/Guidance_Booklet_March_2017__ILB_44_03.17_.pdf |title=Applying for a Passport |publisher=HM Passport Office |accessdate=18 October 2017 }}</ref> In Northern Ireland, for children between the ages of two and eighteen years, only one change of forename(s) and one change of surname may be recorded. In Scotland, it is also possible to record a change of name on the original birth register entry at the General Register Office. However, only one change of forename and three changes of surname are permitted.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gro-scotland.gov.uk/files2/registration/rcn1.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614150953/http://www.gro-scotland.gov.uk/files2/registration/rcn1.pdf |archivedate=14 June 2011 |title=Recording changes of forename(s) and surname(s) in Scotland |publisher=General Register Office for Scotland}}</ref>
===Republic of Ireland=== In the [[Republic of Ireland]], a deed poll of change of name ({{lang-ga|Athrú Ainm de réir Gníomhais Aonpháirtí}}) is obtainable from the Central Office of the [[Four Courts]], Dublin at a cost of €30. Like in the UK, there are very few restrictions on name changes. One is that foreign nationals must also obtain a change of name license from the Irish Naturalisation and Immigration Service. One of Ireland's most noted name changers was the politician [[Seán Dublin Bay Rockall Loftus|Seán Loftus]], who repeatedly added middle names referring to his political views so that they would appear on election ballot papers.
==History== In ''re Parrott, Cox v Parrott'' [1946] Ch 183,<ref>[https://deedpolloffice.com/change-name/law/case-law/Re-Parrott-Cox-v-Parrott-1946-Ch-183 ''Re'' Parrott, Cox ''v'' Parrott <nowiki>[1946]</nowiki> Ch 183]</ref> [[Harry Vaisey|Mr Justice Vaisey]] stated that he did not believe that a deed poll could be used to change a person's [[Christian name]] (first name) – that could be done by only an [[Act of Parliament]]. Deeds that change a person's first name can be registered by the applicant in the Enrolment Books of the Senior Courts of England and Wales, which is located within the Royal Courts of Justice on Strand, London, and they are usually endorsed "Notwithstanding the decision of Mr Justice Vaisey in ''re Parrott, Cox v Parrott'', the applicant wishes the enrolment to proceed".
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.gov.uk/change-name-deed-poll UK Government - Change your name (by deed poll)]
